articles.headline: DeVos Ends Obama-Era Safeguards Aimed at Abuses by For-Profit Colleges
articles.snippet: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos, in her most drastic move to deregulate for-profit colleges, announced she would end a rule to force them to prove the gainful employment of their graduates.
articles.abstract: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos, in her most drastic move to deregulate for-profit colleges, announced she would end a rule to force them to prove the gainful employment of their graduates.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Education Secretary Betsy DeVos formally moved Friday to scrap a regulation that would have forced for-profit colleges to prove that the students they enroll are able to attain decent-paying jobs, the most drastic in a series of policy shifts that will free the scandal-scarred, for-profit sector from safeguards put in effect during the Obama era.

articles.headline: Fidelity Tries Luring Investors With 2 No-Fee Funds. So What’s the Catch?
articles.snippet: The investing giant accelerated a price war by introducing two index mutual funds with no fees. If the move works, Fidelity can sell other products and services to those it attracts.
articles.abstract: The investing giant accelerated a price war by introducing two index mutual funds with no fees. If the move works, Fidelity can sell other products and services to those it attracts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investing just became even cheaper — free, actually.

articles.headline: A Lifelong Political Scrapper, Roger Stone Is Fighting for His Own Legal Future
articles.snippet: Several recent developments in the Russia investigation have placed Mr. Stone in increasing legal jeopardy.
articles.abstract: Several recent developments in the Russia investigation have placed Mr. Stone in increasing legal jeopardy.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a flamboyant veteran of Washington and New York City politics, the campaign strategist Roger J. Stone Jr. has been in any number of knock-’em-down scrapes over the years, reaching back four decades to his early days as a self-described “dirty trickster” in the Nixon administration.

articles.headline: Inside Twitter’s Struggle Over What Gets Banned
articles.snippet: The social media company provided a rare look inside a policy meeting as it struggled with criticism that it left up posts from the conspiracy site Infowars and its creator, Alex Jones.
articles.abstract: The social media company provided a rare look inside a policy meeting as it struggled with criticism that it left up posts from the conspiracy site Infowars and its creator, Alex Jones.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — With his arms folded, Jack Dorsey paced back and forth in a conference room at Twitter’s headquarters on Friday afternoon.
articles.byline: By Cecilia Kang and Kate Conger

articles.headline: Back-to-School Shopping for Districts: Armed Guards, Cameras and Metal Detectors
articles.snippet: The shooting in Parkland, Fla., spurred school districts into reinforcing buildings, hiring armed guards and training staff to handle mass casualty events.
articles.abstract: The shooting in Parkland, Fla., spurred school districts into reinforcing buildings, hiring armed guards and training staff to handle mass casualty events.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARKLAND, Fla. — Fortified by fences and patrolled by more armed personnel, schools will open their doors to students for the start of the new year with a heightened focus on security intended to ease fears about deadly campus shootings.

articles.headline: Turkey’s Financial Crisis Surprised Many. Except This Analyst.
articles.snippet: Tim Lee, an obscure economist who writes an investment newsletter, predicted that Turkey’s currency would collapse. Now, he foresees a broader financial crisis.
articles.abstract: Tim Lee, an obscure economist who writes an investment newsletter, predicted that Turkey’s currency would collapse. Now, he foresees a broader financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the past seven years, Tim Lee has been warning that a financial crisis in Turkey would set off a wider calamity in global markets.

articles.headline: The Journey of the ‘Sex Cult’ Heiress: From Reluctant Recruit to Criminal Defendant
articles.snippet: Clare Bronfman was born into a billion-dollar family. Now she faces federal charges over her involvement with a group called Nxivm.
articles.abstract: Clare Bronfman was born into a billion-dollar family. Now she faces federal charges over her involvement with a group called Nxivm.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2013, with his health failing, the billionaire businessman Edgar M. Bronfman was visited at home by his youngest daughter, Clare. She brought with her a production crew that was making a film about a self-help group called Nxivm.

articles.headline: Trump’s War With Harley-Davidson Has Divided America’s Bikers
articles.snippet: A move by the company has put one of the country’s most iconic brands in the uncomfortable position of clashing with a president who is immensely popular with most of its customers.
articles.abstract: A move by the company has put one of the country’s most iconic brands in the uncomfortable position of clashing with a president who is immensely popular with most of its customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: STURGIS, S.D. — Gary Rathbun rumbled into South Dakota to attend the United States’ pre-eminent gathering of motorcycle enthusiasts atop his Harley-Davidson, a 2009 Ultra Classic that brought him 800 miles from Idaho. It is the 40th Harley he has owned. It is also likely to be his last.

articles.headline: Burying ‘One Child’ Limits, China Pushes Women to Have More Babies
articles.snippet: Worried that an aging population imperils the economy, Beijing is scrambling to stimulate a baby boom after decades of harsh restrictions on births.
articles.abstract: Worried that an aging population imperils the economy, Beijing is scrambling to stimulate a baby boom after decades of harsh restrictions on births.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For decades, China harshly restricted the number of babies that women could have. Now it is encouraging them to have more. It is not going well.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Olivia Mitchell Ryan

articles.headline: The Iraqi Spy Who Infiltrated ISIS
articles.snippet: The story of the mole who posed as a jihadist in the Islamic State, and the most important antiterrorism agency that most people have never heard of.
articles.abstract: The story of the mole who posed as a jihadist in the Islamic State, and the most important antiterrorism agency that most people have never heard of.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The driver was sweating as his white Kia pickup truck sped along a rain-slicked Baghdad highway toward a neighborhood bustling with open-air markets.

articles.headline: Wisconsin Faces a Political Crossroads Tuesday. Which Way Will It Go?
articles.snippet: Democrats hope to swing back in their favor a state that played an unexpectedly pivotal role in President Trump’s victory. But it may be too late.
articles.abstract: Democrats hope to swing back in their favor a state that played an unexpectedly pivotal role in President Trump’s victory. But it may be too late.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAZOMANIE, Wis. — The most memorable part of Scott Walker’s run for president in 2016 was how he ended it: By dissing Donald J. Trump, his chief rival in a crowded race.

articles.headline: Amid Kremlin Victories, Putin Fails to Persuade West on Russian Sanctions
articles.snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin has nimbly exploited differences between Washington and its allies, but he has yet to translate that into fewer sanctions against Russia.
articles.abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin has nimbly exploited differences between Washington and its allies, but he has yet to translate that into fewer sanctions against Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — From Moscow to Washington to capitals in between, the past few days have showcased the way President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia nimbly exploits differences between the United States and its allies.

articles.headline: China Seeks Influence in Europe, One Business Deal at a Time
articles.snippet: A mysterious Chinese company went on a buying binge in the Czech Republic following Xi Jinping’s call for greater sway in the region. What was the cost?
articles.abstract: A mysterious Chinese company went on a buying binge in the Czech Republic following Xi Jinping’s call for greater sway in the region. What was the cost?
articles.lead_paragraph: PRAGUE — When Xi Jinping became the first top Chinese leader to visit the Czech Republic, he was accompanied by a mysterious Chinese tycoon with big political ambitions, money to burn and strong ties to the Czech president.
articles.byline: By David Barboza, Marc Santora and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: As Barnes & Noble Struggles to Find Footing, Founder Takes Heat
articles.snippet: Sales are falling and critics say the company lacks a direction, sometimes seeming to give priority to sales of gifts and tchotchkes over books.
articles.abstract: Sales are falling and critics say the company lacks a direction, sometimes seeming to give priority to sales of gifts and tchotchkes over books.
articles.lead_paragraph: Leonard Riggio radically altered bookselling in America when he bought an ailing New York City bookstore and turned it into a national chain of megastores.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Alter and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: Voting Rights Advocates Used to Have an Ally in the Government. That’s Changing.
articles.snippet: The Obama Justice Department fought voter-ID laws, aggressive purges of voter rolls and dilution of minority votes. Under President Trump, the department often does the opposite.
articles.abstract: The Obama Justice Department fought voter-ID laws, aggressive purges of voter rolls and dilution of minority votes. Under President Trump, the department often does the opposite.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A new voter ID law could shut out many Native Americans from the polls in North Dakota. A strict rule on the collection of absentee ballots in Arizona is being challenged as a form of voter suppression. And officials in Georgia are scrubbing voters from registration rolls if their details do not exactly match other records, a practice that voting rights groups say unfairly targets minority voters.

articles.headline: Trump’s National Security Claim for Tariffs Sets Off Crisis at W.T.O.
articles.snippet: The Trump administration has forced the World Trade Organization into the tough spot of having to make a ruling that could cause problems whatever it does.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration has forced the World Trade Organization into the tough spot of having to make a ruling that could cause problems whatever it does.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s embrace of sweeping tariffs has frustrated allies, lawmakers and businesses across the globe. But its most lasting impact could be to hobble the World Trade Organization.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: The Rise and Fall of Paul Manafort: Greed, Deception and Ego
articles.snippet: The former Trump campaign chairman’s trial has ripped away the facade of a man who worked for the campaign for free, intimating he was too rich to need the money.
articles.abstract: The former Trump campaign chairman’s trial has ripped away the facade of a man who worked for the campaign for free, intimating he was too rich to need the money.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — A week before the Trump presidential campaign announced that it had hired Paul Manafort, a Yankees ticket specialist alerted him that his annual season tickets would soon be arriving at his 43rd-floor apartment at Trump Tower in New York.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere, Kenneth P. Vogel and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Banks and Retailers Are Tracking How You Type, Swipe and Tap
articles.snippet: Biometrics are moving way beyond fingerprints: To fight fraud, companies are building databases on people’s behaviors and movements.
articles.abstract: Biometrics are moving way beyond fingerprints: To fight fraud, companies are building databases on people’s behaviors and movements.
articles.lead_paragraph: When you’re browsing a website and the mouse cursor disappears, it might be a computer glitch — or it might be a deliberate test to find out who you are.

articles.headline: Tesla Board Surprised by Elon Musk’s Tweet on Taking Carmaker Private
articles.snippet: The chief executive is said to have written his Twitter post last week in haste. But he said Monday he had Saudi financial backing for a buyout plan.
articles.abstract: The chief executive is said to have written his Twitter post last week in haste. But he said Monday he had Saudi financial backing for a buyout plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: An abrupt tweet last week by Elon Musk about the prospect of taking Tesla private was dashed off with little forethought, and had not been cleared ahead of time with the company’s board, two people familiar with the chain of events said Monday.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Neal E. Boudette, Landon Thomas Jr. and Kate Kelly

articles.headline: ‘Don’t Run This Year’: The Perils for Republican Women Facing a Flood of Resistance
articles.snippet: The energy in the midterms is working against female Republican candidates who are reluctant or unable to claim any advantage to being a woman among voters.
articles.abstract: The energy in the midterms is working against female Republican candidates who are reluctant or unable to claim any advantage to being a woman among voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN CAPISTRANO, Calif. — Diane Harkey, the Republican candidate for California’s 49th Congressional District, recognizes that President Trump “doesn’t make women real comfortable.”

articles.headline: F.B.I. Agent Peter Strzok, Who Criticized Trump in Texts, Is Fired
articles.snippet: Mr. Strzok was one of the F.B.I.’s top counterintelligence officials. But his disparaging texts about President Trump handed a weapon to conservatives assailing the Russia investigation.
articles.abstract: Mr. Strzok was one of the F.B.I.’s top counterintelligence officials. But his disparaging texts about President Trump handed a weapon to conservatives assailing the Russia investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Peter Strzok, the F.B.I. senior counterintelligence agent who disparaged President Trump in inflammatory text messages and helped oversee the Hillary Clinton email and Russia investigations, has been fired for violating bureau policies, Mr. Strzok’s lawyer said Monday.
articles.byline: By Adam Goldman and Michael S. Schmidt
